Award.AwardTitle: IUSE: Collaborative Project: Building Virtual Research, Interactive, Service, and Experiential Learning Modules for Cyber Security Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will help address the critical need for more graduates who have a foundation in cybersecurity concepts and skills. It will utilize a cyberinfrastructure learning experience, through the use of a mobile cloud-based virtual laboratory (MCVE), to introduce cybersecurity material to computer science (CS), information technology (IT), and computer engineering (CE) students at Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis (IUPUI), Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT), and Tennessee State University. Existing courses can be enhanced with the addition of relevant lab modules, and this approach will make it possible for students to see directly how computer science and engineering concepts can be used in real problem-solving. This project will promote recruitment and retention of CS, CE, and IT students for careers in cybersecurity. In addition, a number of professional development and outreach workshops will help increase the number of university faculty prepared to offer courses that utilize the same underlying system, and also prepare high school teachers to, at minimum, make students aware of cybersecurity issues and practices.

The educational activities involved in this project will use the RISE (Research, Interactive, Service, and Experiential) learning components in order to teach cybersecurity concepts and skills. The learning components will utilize MCVE as the mechanism for delivering the RISE laboratory modules. The MCVE infrastructure is based on smartphones and cloud computing resources that are available at the three universities and through the Amazon EC2 system. The cloud security testbed at IUPUI and the RIT computation grid will be used to create virtual machines and network topologies on which security experiments can be conducted. The TSU Cloud at Tennessee State will be used to serve a malware database. Finally, the Amazon Web Services can be used for security implementation experiments. This collection of resources will allow students who work with the MCVE to experiment with a range of system, network, and cloud configurations. Students will have the opportunity to work with MCVE through numerous courses that span the CS, IT, and CE curricula, addressing secure programming, cryptography, security architecture, network security, and security policy. Project evaluation will be done with a mixed methods approach, specifically focusing on the skills and increased competency students gain as a result of the RISE lab modules, change in student understanding of the connection between cybersecurity concepts and techniques, changes in recruitment and retention of CS, CE, and IT students. Evaluation will include student surveys, learning outcome measures, instructor interviews, and classroom observations. This project will be funded by the Division of Undergraduate Education, through the IUSE program, and the Division of Graduate Education, through the SFS program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the use of smartphones and other mobile devices increases, so does the wealth of information on these devices. Although this wealth of information may draw attention from malicious individuals, many users of these devices do not consider the security vulnerabilities present as significantly as they keep antivirus software on their PCs or laptops. Enhancing the scientific knowledge about security for mobile devices and networks includes education of the students who will be part of teams to study and combat these risks.

The overarching goal of this proposal was to advance cybersecurity education through the collaborative design and implementation of Research, Interactive, Service, and Experiential (RISE) learning  "plug-in" components. These components utilize an innovative mobile cloud virtual environment and a smartphone app as the interface. These plug-ins as well as the mobile cloud virtual environment were used and evaluated in curriculum development, faculty professional development, and partnership development.  This collaborative team (from IUPUI, RIT and TSU) completed RISE lab modules focused on smartphone apps vulnerability analysis, development of the user behavior modeling for building user profiles, and developed smartphone security lab modules on the Global Environment for Network Innovations (GENI).

The specific objective of the modules developed at Tennessee State University was to analyze the behavior of malware affecting smartphone applications and smartphone cloud interface. We also identified the lectures and hands on activities in Experiential and Research learning modules.

Specific accomplishments at Tennessee State University included the following.

1)      Completing the development of RISE lab modules focused on smartphone application security, and smartphone network security at Tennessee State University. The malware analysis tools were updated to reflect new malware and updated development environment.

Three experiments have been prepared which can be incorporated as modules in selected courses and workshop sessions. A sandbox environment in TSU?s private cloud to facilitate scalable analysis of malware has also been developed.

2)      Completing the development of the user behavior modeling for building user profiles, which can predict the application usage on the smartphones. A user behavior model approach for app prediction based on Hidden Markov Models, which collects user application interactions with associated contextual data. From the prediction analysis, parameters such as last used application and combination of parameters such as last used app and day, last used app and time generated high application prediction accuracy among the other considered parameters .  The top 5 prediction apps based on last used app, day and time was highly accurate for all the users. One limitation in this model is that the user needed an internet connection during the system processing and storing the models on the server. User group profiling to learn the common application usage behavioral patterns of users based on gender, age, occupation and internet usage. Also, clustered similar behavior using K -means clustering method and tested these clusters using Kullback-Leibler divergence.

The project provided training opportunities to students at TSU. Students who worked in the development of modules learned Android Emulation, Static and Dynamic analysis, and machine learning tools. The major skills they gained over the course of the development are: problem-solving, creative thinking, critical thinking, teamwork, communication, and presentation skills. Students involved in the testing phases learned the process of conducting experiments with real users, collecting data and training models.  The students have also learned how to develop modules which can be incorporated in undergraduate/graduate courses and workshops.

The collaborative team organized three workshops on the three campus and invited participants from other campus to attend them where student and faculty participants were trained with the experiential and service modules that were developed. Tennessee State University organized and hosted one such workshop focused on several machine learning techniques to allow static and dynamic analysis of malware on mobile devices.
